No Poverty.justification: B cites urban policy analysis (都市政策分析) as a basis, implying a link to poverty through urban policy; A has no explicit poverty-related evidence.

Zero Hunger.justification: Neither model provides explicit evidence connecting to Zero Hunger; both score near-zero.

Good Health and Well-being.justification: B links urban transportation and land-use control to public health outcomes; A lacks evidence.

Quality Education.justification: Both provide minimal/no explicit tie to global education goals; comparable evidence.

Gender Equality.justification: Neither model provides explicit gender-equality indicators; both near-zero.

Clean Water and Sanitation.justification: No explicit water/sanitation focus in course; both provide little/no evidence.

Affordable and Clean Energy.justification: No explicit energy/affordability focus; both near-zero.

Decent Work and Economic Growth.justification: B provides clear explicit link to urban economics and agglomeration; higher score and stronger rationale.

Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure.justification: B explicitly ties urban development, planning, and transport to infrastructure concepts; stronger evidence than A.

Reduced Inequalities.justification: B references urban policy, rent theory, and land-use analysis addressing spatial/economic inequalities; A lacks.

Sustainable Cities and Communities.justification: Both models assign top score and explicit links to urban economics and planning; comparable.

Responsible Consumption and Production.justification: B associates land-use control with resource efficiency; A lacks explicit link.

Climate Action.justification: B connects urban transport and development topics to climate action; A has no evidence.

Life Below Water.justification: Neither model cites water-focused content; both near-zero.

Life on Land.justification: B connects land-use control to terrestrial ecosystems; A has no explicit link.

Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions.justification: B links urban policy analysis and land use to governance and institutions; A weaker.

Partnerships for the Goals.justification: B references teamwork and following international knowledge; stronger evidence than A.

No Poverty.justification: Model B correctly infers a connection through '都市政策分析' (Urban Policy Analysis), which can indirectly address poverty issues in urban contexts. Model A is too strict with a score of 0.001.

Zero Hunger.justification: Both models correctly identify no direct or indirect evidence in the syllabus related to hunger or food security.

Good Health and Well-being.justification: Model B reasonably infers a connection through '都市交通' (Urban Transportation) and '土地使用管制' (Land Use Control), which can indirectly impact public health and well-being. Model A misses this plausible link.

Quality Education.justification: Both models correctly identify that while the course is educational, it does not focus on the SDG's goal of improving education systems or access.

Gender Equality.justification: Both models correctly identify no evidence in the syllabus related to gender equality.

Clean Water and Sanitation.justification: Both models correctly identify no explicit or implicit evidence in the syllabus related to clean water or sanitation.

Affordable and Clean Energy.justification: Both models correctly identify no evidence in the syllabus related to affordable and clean energy.

Decent Work and Economic Growth.justification: Both models identify strong explicit links. Model B's score of 9.2 is slightly more appropriate given the direct relevance of 'Urban Economics' and '聚集經濟及不經濟' (agglomeration economies) to economic growth.

Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure.justification: Both models identify strong explicit links. Model B's inclusion of '都市規劃的操作能力' (Urban Planning operational ability) as key evidence, alongside '都市交通' (Urban Transportation), provides a slightly more comprehensive and direct connection to infrastructure development.

Reduced Inequalities.justification: Model B makes a strong inferred connection, almost explicit, using '都市政策分析' (Urban Policy Analysis), '都市競租理論分析' (Urban Rent Theory Analysis), and '都市土地利用之一般均衡分析' (General Equilibrium Analysis of Urban Land Use), all of which are highly relevant to understanding and addressing urban inequalities. Model A completely misses this connection.

Sustainable Cities and Communities.justification: Both models correctly identify this SDG as the most directly relevant to the course, providing excellent explicit evidence and assigning a perfect score.

Responsible Consumption and Production.justification: Model B plausibly infers a connection through '土地使用管制' (Land Use Control), which can influence resource efficiency and consumption/production patterns in urban areas. Model A misses this link.

Climate Action.justification: Model B makes a strong inferred connection through '都市交通' (Urban Transportation) and '都市發展之議題' (urban development issues), which are directly related to emissions and urban resilience. Model A misses this connection.

Life Below Water.justification: Both models correctly identify no evidence in the syllabus related to marine life or oceans.

Life on Land.justification: Model B plausibly infers a connection through '土地使用管制' (Land Use Control), which directly impacts terrestrial ecosystems and biodiversity in urban and surrounding areas. Model A misses this link.

Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions.justification: Model B provides a slightly more comprehensive justification by including both '都市政策分析' (Urban Policy Analysis) and '土地使用管制' (Land Use Control), both of which relate to governance, regulations, and institutional frameworks in cities. Model A only includes '都市政策分析'.

Partnerships for the Goals.justification: Model B correctly identifies the learning outcomes '協調中型團隊合作的能力' (Ability to coordinate medium-sized team cooperation) and 'Follow國際新知的能力' (Ability to follow international new knowledge) as foundational for partnerships. Model A completely misses these relevant points.
